message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a defect in oxidative phosphorylation, which is most commonly caused by mitochondrial disorders. Therefore, the muscle biopsy is most likely to show subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria. Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers is seen in muscular dystrophy, which presents differently. Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is seen in glycogen storage diseases, which is characterized by hepatosplenomegaly and hypoglycemia. Endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is seen in inflammatory myopathies such as polymyositis and dermatomyositis, which present differently.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a defect in oxidative phosphorylation, which is commonly seen in mitochondrial disorders. The subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria is a characteristic finding in mitochondrial myopathies. Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers is seen in muscular dystrophies. Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is seen in glycogen storage diseases. Endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is seen in dermatomyositis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a defect in oxidative phosphorylation. Subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria is often seen in mitochondrial myopathies, which are a group of disorders resulting from defects in oxidative phosphorylation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a metabolic condition characterized by a defect in oxidative phosphorylation, and muscle biopsy is likely to show subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria, as this is a common finding in mitochondrial myopathies. Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers is seen in muscular dystrophies, intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is seen in glycogen storage diseases, and endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is seen in autoimmune myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The low pH and elevated lactate concentration suggest a defect in oxidative phosphorylation, which is characteristic of mitochondrial myopathy. Therefore, the microscopic examination will most likely show subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria. Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers is characteristic of muscular dystrophy, intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is characteristic of glycogen storage diseases, and endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is characteristic of inflammatory myopathy, none of which are suggested by the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biochemical abnormalities indicate a metabolic disorder affecting oxidative phosphorylation. The muscle biopsy in this disorder is most likely to show subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria. Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers is seen in muscular dystrophies, intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is seen in glycogen storage diseases, and endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is seen in inflammatory myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a metabolic disorder involving oxidative phosphorylation. Subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria is a common finding in these disorders, while the other options are not typically associated with them.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest a metabolic disorder. The most likely finding in a muscle biopsy for a defect in oxidative phosphorylation is subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria. Fibrofatty replacement of normal muscle fibers is seen in muscular dystrophy. Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is seen in glycogen storage diseases. Endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is seen in inflammatory myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, as well as the suspicion of a defect in oxidative phosphorylation, suggest a mitochondrial disorder. The subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria is a hallmark finding in mitochondrial disorders. The other options listed are not associated with mitochondrial disorders but are seen in other muscle disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is suspected to have a metabolic condition affecting oxidative phosphorylation, which is related to mitochondrial dysfunction. Therefore, subsarcolemmal accumulation of mitochondria is the most likely finding on muscle biopsy. Fibrofatty replacement of muscle fibers is seen in muscular dystrophies. Intermyofibrillar accumulation of glycogen is seen in glycogen storage diseases, and endomysial inflammation with T cell infiltration is seen in dermatomyositis.
